awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Single-Crystal X-Ray Diffractometer for Research and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. The University of Arizona is acquiring a single crystal X-ray diffractometer (SCXRD) to support Professor Elisa Tomat and colleagues Wei Wang, Jon Njardarson, Thomas Gianetti and Tai Kong. In general, an X-ray diffractometer allows accurate and precise measurements of the full three-dimensional structure of a molecule, including bond distances and angles, and provides accurate information about the spatial arrangement of a molecule relative to neighboring molecules. The studies described here impact many areas, including organic and inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry, and biochemistry. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of undergraduate and graduate students, including veterans, in chemistry and biochemistry at this Hispanic Serving Institution as well as collaborators from other regional universities in the Southwest (Arizona/New Mexico region). 

The award of this diffractometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It especially impacts the exploration of coordination chemistry strategies in bioinorganic redox reactivity and cell biology and the design of organic reactions such as those for total natural product synthesis. The instrumentation is also used for developing carbenium-based ligands for catalytic applications and the development of chemical tools for biology and potential drug discovery.  The instrument also serves researchers searching for natural-product-based compounds that may act as therapeutics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported the acquisition of an X-ray diffractometer for the advanced structural characterization of small molecules and materials in the multiuser X-ray diffraction (XRD) facility housed in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry (CBC) at the University of Arizona. The new Bruker D8 VENTURE diffractometer has a high-sensitivity detector and two microfocus X-ray sources with copper and molybdenum anodes. Since its installation, this state-of-the-art instrument has enhanced the research, training, and educational experiences of our broad user community, which includes research groups in our department, campus, and surrounding region.

The new diffractometer enables research progress on multiple projects by providing definitive structural information on new compounds, including catalysts, monomers for polymeric materials, drug candidates, and molecular components of batteries. Several dozen datasets have been collected and the fully refined structures have been deposited in the international repository of small-molecule crystal structures. The findings obtained using the new instrument have already appeared in doctoral dissertations and peer-reviewed publications, and a number of manuscripts are currently in preparation in several groups. 

The presence of the instrument in the XRD facility also provides excellent opportunities for scientific training and professional development. Several graduate students and postdoctoral associates have been trained by the facility manager in safety protocols, data collection, and analysis. These trainees gain an important skillset as part of their learning journey in CBC.

Furthermore, the new instrument makes an impact on the departmental educational mission through the inorganic laboratory course CHEM 412 (Inorganic Preparations), which is part of the required undergraduate curriculum for chemistry majors and includes a crystallography module. Every semester, the students prepare crystalline samples and visit the XRD facility for their characterization work. Learning about the capabilities and methods of contemporary research techniques and instrumentation is a key component of our upper-division coursework.

Overall, the PI Dr Elisa Tomat and the co-PIs anticipate that the new diffractometer supported by this award will continue to be central to our research work and educational efforts in upcoming years.

Modified by: Elisa Tomat
